dialogues.text: "They liked her. They loved her. They regarded her as one of the People. She was the People's Princess, and that is how she will remain in our hearts forever.."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN watches in disbelief. Her knuckles whiten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I can't bear it. gets to her feet) I'm going to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following morning. A bare flagpole. No flag flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the flowers left by mourners outside the palace gates growing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large ceremonial room. Elaborate chinoiserie. Ming vase Inside, some thirty or forty OFFICIALS, many uniformed, s around a table. Among them: the CHIEF CONSTABLE of the METROPOLITAN police, the heads of the FIRE SERVICE and AMBULANCE SERVICE, military OFFICERS, representatives fro the three palaces, Kensington Palace, (DIANA's court), St James's Palace, (CHARLES's court) and Buckingham Palace, QUEEN's court), representatives from the Intelligence and Police Protection services, experts in protocol, and fina representatives from the SPENCER FAMILY and Downing Stree (among them ALASTAIR CAMPBELL).

dialogues.speaker: L
dialogues.text: ORD AIRLIE, (whom we met at RAF Northolt), checks the tim It's ten o'clock. He raps on a table, calling the meeting order..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. It's ten o'clock. Let's make a start. Thank you all for coming at such notice. I think we all agree this is an extraordinarily sensitive occasion which presents us with tremendous challenges logistically...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD AIRLIE(cont'd) (a beat) ...constitutionally.. (a beat) ..practically... (a beat) ...diplomatically.. (a beat) ...procedurally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALASTAIR privately rolls his eyes..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10, Downing Street. A car pulls up. ALASTAIR CAMPBELL get out. Visibly in a bad mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY BLAIR is in his office, surrounded by his AIDES, wor in shirtsleeves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "..after eighteen years of Opposition, of frustration and despair, I am proud, privileged, to stand before you as the new Prime Minister..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Labour Prime Minister..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I want to set an ambitious course to modernise this country. To breathe new life into our institutions. To make privilege something for the many, not the few. So that we become nothing less than a beacon to the world..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Thump', the door opens, ALASTAIR CAMPBELL enters, clutch the day's newspapers..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody hell! You think the Royals are nutters! You should meet their flunkeys! Two and a half-hours on whether she should be carried in a hearse or a gun-carriage. (taps head, "Nuts") Anyway, raves in the press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALASTAIR dumps the papers on the desk..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This lot call you "The Nation's Mourner in Chief", this lot say you're "The only person who has correctly judged the mood of the country". Even the "Mail".. (disdainfully holding the paper between finger and thumb) ..was impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALASTAIR drops the papers on TONY's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "People's Princess", mate. You owe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LASTAIR goes. TONY watches, then jumps up, opens the door His AIDE calls after him, covering the phone..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him to hang on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY follows ALASTAIR out, calls after him..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY (cont'd) So it's decided? It's going to be a public funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. On Saturday. A whopper. The Abbey. The works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Has anyone told the Queen yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunno. No doubt some flunkey will be despatched. Grovelling on all fours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY smiles imagining the prospect, goes back into his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Knock', a knock on the door, and ROBIN JANVRIN enters carrying a large file. He bows first to the QUEEN..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..then to the QUEEN MOTHER..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN looks up..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can we do for you, Robin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANVRIN braces himself. This is not going to be easy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, there was a meeting at the Palace this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About the funeral arrangements, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord Chamberlain faxed over these plans for you to consider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANVRIN puts a large file on her desk..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is now general agreement, Ma'am, that a public funeral would be more appropriate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he QUEEN perceptibly bristles..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: nd what form will it take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the moment, they're suggesting.. (clears throat) And of course these are early days..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANVRIN braces himself. Shoots a nervous look at the QUEE MOTHER..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANVRIN (cont'd) ...basing it on Tay Bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN MOTHER looks up. Horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tay Bridge..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stunned silence..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B-but that's the code name for my funeral?    J

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ndeed, Ma'am. (a beat) But it would be for practical reasons only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANVRIN is dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the only one which has been.. (treads delicately) ..`rehearsed'. The only one that could be put together..in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN MOTHER needs to sit down..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I supervised those plans myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, and the Lord Chamberlain was at pains to stress the spirit of the occasion will be quite different. a beat) For example, in place of four hundred soldiers marching behind the coffin, the suggestion is that four hundred representatives from the Princess's various charities march behind the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN MOTHER's eyes widen..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that instead of foreign Heads of State and Crown heads of Europe, the guests would include a sprinkling of actors of stage and screen, fashion designers and other.. (clears throat) ...celebrities..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celebrities..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN looks ashen. The QUEEN MOTHER is pouring hersel drink..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH (cont'd) Wa..was there anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANVRIN bows, and leaves. Then stops, remembering..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. One other thing. The Police Commissioner was keen that you consider the idea of a condolence book. (a beat) It would give the growing crowds something to do. Make marshalling them easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted) Yes, of course..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANVRIN reaches the door..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he QUEEN looks up..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W hat flowers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANVRIN (cont'd) The flowers that have been left outside Buckingham palace. Currently they're blocking the path through the main gate, and will make things difficult for the Changing of the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Then move them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANVRIN flinches slightly in anticipation..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, the Lord Chamberlain was wondering whether we shouldn't leave the flowers, and send the Guards through the North Gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN looks thrown..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ye-es. Of course. chastened) Quite right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Rrrrinng', the phone rings. TONY is sitting at his desk one AIDE. A knock on the door. Another AIDE enters..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: tephen Lamport on one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY looks up. Irritated at being disturbed..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prince of Wales's private secretary. In Balmoral. covering phone) He said it was urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY rolls his eyes, then picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ood afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEPHEN LAMPORT, Private Secretary to the Prince of Wales, sits at a desk. CHARLES is also present, listening..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prince of Wales wanted me to thank you again for your kind words yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He feels you and he...are modern men...of similar mind... (a beat) ...who could work well together at this difficult time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY shoots a quizzical look..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, please thank his Highness, and assure him that he can count on my full support. At all times. (a beat) Was that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY hangs up. He turns to his AIDE..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY (cont'd) Bizarre. Why is Charles doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creeping up to me like this. He did it at the airport when he asked me to `deal' with his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ecause he knows that if the Queen continues to get it wrong over Diana, it won't be long before the Royals become public enemy no 1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a beat) Terrified of being shot, apparently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who, Charles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His people have already been onto us asking for extra protection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He probably thinks if he's seen to be on our side, the Queen will be the one left in the firing line, not him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? So it's OK for his mother to take the bullet, not him? shakes head) What a family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN, in tatty old Barbour, head-scarf, Wellington boots, loads Corgis and picnic hampers into the back of a old Land Rover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She climbs into an old, muddy Jeep, and starts the oily, smoky diesel engine. As she begins to drive out, she turn corner, and passes CHARLES who is climbing into his much smarter, luxury, leather-upholstered jeep..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up at Craigghead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES climbs in. The QUEEN notices how extravagantly dressed he is. A kilt and tailored hunting jacket..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES (cont'd) Want me to drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARLES shudders at the rough interior of the car, the mud spattered windows, the hard, uncomfortable ride..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were going to get a new

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: one of these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for? It's perfectly all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engine splutters as she changes gear. The car lurches forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he QUEEN drives hard through woods, dust kicking up in th old Land Rover's wake. It's a bone-shaking ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARLES stares out of the window, lost in thought..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking last night what Diana might have done had it been me that died in the tunnel in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN privately rolls her eyes..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She would certainly have taken the boys to Paris. I rather regret not doing that now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? And expose them to the media? It would have been a dreadful thing to do. They're much better off here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, whatever else you may have thought of Diana - she was a wonderful mother. a beat) She adored those boys. And never let them forget it. a beat) Always warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he QUEEN's hands tighten on the steering wheel..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And physical. a beat) Never afraid to show her feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially whenever a photographer was in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she MAY have encouraged all that, but still..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES looks out of the window. His eyes mist over..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES (cont'd) That was always the extraordinary thing about her. Her weaknesses and transgressions only seemed to make the public love her MORE. Yet ours only make them hate us. Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES looks up..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES (cont'd) Why do they hate us so much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN mutters under her breath...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not `us', dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not having heard) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN salutes GAME-KEEPERS who remove their hats as t QUEEN roars past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday, when we drove the coffin back into London, there was a noise. A bang. I don't mind telling you I thought it was a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES's hands wring in anxiety..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES (cont'd) I thought someone had taken a shot at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he QUEEN hits the brakes, and pulls up. Visibly irritated her son's weakness. She opens the door, and steps out..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you go on without me? I'm going to walk back..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It looks like rain.. (the DOGS jump out) And I'm not in the mood for stalking anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES knows better than to contradict his mother. He ge into the driving seat, puts on the safety belt, and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Land Rover disappears in a cloud of dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN straightens, then notices her shoe-laces are undone. The DOGS bark excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! My shoe-lace is undone. You don't want me to trip and hurt myself, do you? a beat) You wouldn't get any proper walks then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN blissfully chatters away to the DOGS. So much easier than people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Done. Now who knows the way home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he DOGS yap excitedly, immediately scamper off in the direction of the castle..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You clever things!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARLES's Land Rover drives up into the hills, into spectacular landscape. A mile or two ahead, above the tre line, PHILIP, the two PRINCES and STALKERS carrying guns, crawl on their bellies in pursuit of their quarry..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred years ahead of them, the STAG, unaware of the danger, imperiously, grazes on the grass..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN, granite-faced, still smarting from her row wit CHARLES, is in her bedroom. A nightcap martini is on her bedside table. She is writing her diary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILIP emerges from the bathroom, appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke to Charles this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: flicker of coldness behind her eyes..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was good enough to share with me his views on motherhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: TV plays in the corner. DIANA, starved thin, panda-eyes, the infamous Martin Bashir `PANORAMA' interview..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How wonderful Diana was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's changing his tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a natural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..I think..they see me as a threat of some kind..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRINCE PHILIP sees what's on television, then grimaces..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puckers face) Oh, for God's sake..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's got a point. Maybe we are partly to blame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILIP goes over to the television..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't watch this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, wait. Leave it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILIP stares at the screen..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Every strong woman in history has had to walk down a similar path.."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We encouraged the match. And signed off on it. Both of us. a beat) You were very enthusiastic, remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a nice girl. Then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "And I think it's this strength that causes the confusion and the fear."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRINCE PHILIP shakes his head..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I was sure he'd give the other one up. Or, at least make sure his wife towed the line. (a gesture) Isn't that what everyone does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flicker behind the QUEEN's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her knuckles momentarily whiten. Unaware, PHILIP stares a the television..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Why is she strong? Where is she getting it from? Where is she going to take it? How is she going to use it?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rolls his eyes in disbelief..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRINCE PHILIP (cont'd) I can't bear it any more. If you're watching, I'll sleep in here. Early start tomorrow.. (kisses her on the forehead) See you in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHILIP goes, leaving the QUEEN staring. Still stinging fr his remark about adultery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZAP', she angrily hits the remote. The picture goes black

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY BLAIR and CHERIE at home, watching television. It's o'clock. The KIDS are in bed, but their TOYS are still st around the sitting-room. TONY is tidying them up into box

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON SCREEN: British historian DAVID STARKEY is lambasting CHARLES. TONY and CHERIE sit on the sofa, watching television, eating pasta on their knees. STARKEY defends QUEEN. Part of an older generation. She knows no better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHERIE (cont'd) How much of all this could be the first stirrings of..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W hat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..I don't know...something more interesting. Maybe this time people have finally seen them for what they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunch of freeloading, emotionally retarded...nutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rolls eyes) That's just absurd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? They exist in a ludicrous cocoon of privilege and wealth. They don't pay tax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen alone costs us what? Thirty, forty million a year..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY reaches the door, and turns..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ot you, too. Look...if you want to have a serious conversation about this..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..about the Constitution..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: e don't HAVE one..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...or about ways in which we as a Government could begin to phase out hereditary privileges, then fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating plates) If you're going, take the dishes..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY comes back to take the dirty plates..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But spare me the whole.."off with their heads" thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it insults your intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The case for reform is simple and obvious. It is in principle wrong and absurd that people should wield power on the basis of birth, not merit or election." (a beat) YOUR words, not mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY is momentarily thrown..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe now I've grown up. a beat) It's unimaginable this country being a republic. Certainly in her lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because...no would would wear it. (can't help laughing at the idea) No one WANTS it. (gestures) It's just...daft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY heads for the door..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a mother thing, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY turns..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about it. If she were still alive, wouldn't Hazel be exactly the same age? Whenever you talk about your mother, you mention her stoicism. Her frugality. Her sense of duty. The fact she was brought up in the way. Well c'mon..? (a beat) Who does THAT sound like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to do the washing-up.          F

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALASTAIR and TONY walk through the labyrinthine corridors busy offices..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, the good news is that the Palace has agreed to video screens in the Royal Parks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the bad news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash barriers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hey're now predicting more than two million people will descend on London, and there aren't enough barriers to line the route. So we've gone cap in hand to the French for theirs. And there's something else I think you should see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALASTAIR leads TONY into..

dialogues.speaker: T
dialogues.text: TONY follows ALASTAIR into an office where a television p in the corner. Several young AIDES and INTERNS are watchi recording, making notes. Shirtsleeves, feet on desks. Informal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we run that piece again? You're going to love this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An INTERN puts in a video, hits the `play' button. ON SCR several members of the public complain about the royals. watches for a moment, then..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I know all this..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ne member of the public complains about the flag..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me. There isn't a flag flying at half mast above Buckingham Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY rolls his eyes to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God. Will someone save these people from themselves.. (irritated) F ine. I'll call Balmoral...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY turns away, walks towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Planet Zog'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because as Prime Minister of this country, I've really got nothing better to do..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY walks out..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ROYAL FAMILY is gathered for a bar-be-cue lunch. At a distance, the BOYS, are in the river, being taught fishin a GHILLIE..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRINCE PHILIP stands by a barbecue, struggling to get the fire to light. The QUEEN MOTHER is in another corner..

dialogues.text: LAND ROVER pulls up. The QUEEN gets out with her dogs. Sh notices PHILIP's struggle with the bar-be-cue..

dialogues.text: Candles are burning. Incense sticks. There are pictures o DIANA, and mini-shrines. Poems have been written.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY watches intently. Behind him, the door opens and ALASTAIR enters..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sent a copy of the Queen's speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALISTAIR holds it between finger and thumb..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might want to scrape the frost off it first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALASTAIR passes it to TONY..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made a couple of changes. So it sounds like it comes from a human being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALASTAIR turns, walks towards the door..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and one bit of good news. The old boot's FINALLY agreed to pay respects at Diana's coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY spins round, eyes flashing in anger..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know when you get it wrong, you REALLY get it wrong. a beat) That woman has given her whole life in service to her people - fifty years doing a job she NEVER wanted - a job she watched kill her father. She's executed it with dignity, honour and, as far as I can tell, without a single blemish - and now we line up baying for her blood - why? Because she's struggling to lead the world in mourning for a woman who threw everything she offered back in her face, and who seemed, in the last few years, to be committed twenty-four seven to destroy everything she holds dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY storms off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN continues to read the hand-written messages for DIANA, "We love you." "Rest with the angels, Diana". "You touched us with your love."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: nd also some which are downright hostile. "You were too g for them." "They have your blood on their hands."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he QUEEN stares, visibly shocked, then..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind her, a small GIRL approaches, holding a bouquet of flowers. She stops, in front of the QUEEN..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh..hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he LITTLE GIRL tries to curtsey..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH (cont'd) Would you like me to place them for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (visibly shocked) For me..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN is thrown. Suddenly looks utterly lost. Vulnera almost childlike. Her eyes are puffy and swollen, as thou she is fighting tears..

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: ROWDS of MOURNERS watch intently. The QUEEN takes the flowers, then turns and walks away, visibly shaken..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A television CREW is rigging lights in the Chinese Room i Buckingham Palace. JANVRIN enters and crosses the room. CAMERAS are being fixed to tripods..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN sits in a corner going through her speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Majesty, there's a last minute addition from Downing Street. They're suggesting adding `..and as a grandmother..' here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN makes a note on the text..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH (cont'd) "So what I say to you now, as your Queen and as a grandmother, I say from my heart."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you can say it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have a choice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN turns as SOUND RECORDERS fix a clip-mike to her dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're ready for you, your Majesty..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just to confirm this is going out live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you'll be at the front of the six o'clock news on all the channels

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN is led over to where the DIRECTOR has placed a chair and table in front of the cameras and lights..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Ten seconds, everyone..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN sits at her desk. Final touches from hair and m up. The MALL is clearly visible. The QUEEN holds the spee in front of her..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIRECTOR (cont'd) Five, four..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We close on the QUEEN's face, and..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since last Saturday's dreadful news we have seen, throughout Britain and the world, an overwhelming expression of sadness at Diana's death..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRINCE PHILIP and PRINCE CHARLES watch. PHILIP clenches h jaw muscles in irritation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he QUEEN continues..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have all been trying in our different ways to cope. The initial shock is often succeeded by a mixture of other feelings. Disbelief, incomprehension, anger and concern for those who remain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY and CHERIE BLAIR watch from their apartment..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have all felt these emotions in these last few days. So what I say to you now, as your Queen and as a grandmother, I say from my heart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY flinches in sympathy as she says the line. CHERIE notices this, then..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Heart"? What "heart". She doesn't mean a word of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the point. What she's doing is extraordinary. (points to the TV) That's how you survive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHERIE turns, and stares..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to you! A week ago you were the great moderniser, making speeches about the "People's Princess", now you've gone weak at the knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY bristles with irritation..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why I'm surprised. In the end, all Labour Prime Ministers go ga- ga for her Maj.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope that tomorrow we can all, wherever we are, join in expressing our grief at Diana's loss, and gratitude for her all-too-short life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN draws to a close. Her face is inscrutable. The DIRECTOR prepares his CREW to wind up..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH (cont'd) May those who died rest in peace and may we, each and every one of us..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH (cont'd) ..thank God for someone who made many, many people happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN holds her expression for the camera. Then..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out) And we're out..!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN's face relaxes. As does everyone in the room. A huge, collective breathing out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IRECTOR (cont'd) Thank you, your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the QUEEN doesn't acknowledge him. She removes her cl mike, and hands it to the DIRECTOR..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..then walks over to a waiting PRINCE PHILIP, who protectively extends an arm. The QUEEN and PRINCE PHILIP leave the room. People are left staring awkwardly at one another..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVER THIS: we FADE IN the sound of a haunting, elegiac hy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A soloist sings "Libera me, Domine" from Verdi's Requiem, Westminster Abbey as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUESTS, (including TOM CRUISE, TON HANKS, NICOLE KIDMAN a STEVEN SPIELBERG), arrive with swollen, red eyes, for the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UCIANO PAVAROTTI also attends - along with STING, TRUDI STYLER, BILL and HILARY CLINTON, ELTON JOHN, MOHAMMED AL- FAYED, CLIFF RICHARD, QUEEN NOOR...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY and CHERIE BLAIR take their positions at the front o the church. The First Couple of Great Britain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIANA's coffin is driven away. Showered by flowers all th way to her final resting place at Althorp.

dialogues.speaker: T
dialogues.text: he entire distraught, tearful NATION it seems, has come o onto the streets to pay their final respects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The face of TONY BLAIR stares back from a bathroom mirror CHERIE is proudly tying his tie. Checking his appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in the family apartment above 11, Downing Street. CHERIE puts the finishing touches to his appearance..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We notice her appearance has become even more stylish. Go is her spiky hair. And the rough edges. Every inch the Fi Lady. They've both come a long way in a short time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? Off to see your girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope she shows you some respect this time. It's quite a debt of gratitude she owes you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHERIE straightens his tie..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr "Saviour of the Monarchy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: doubt she'll see it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY's motorcade sweeps into Buckingham Palace. Doors are opened by his PROTECTION OFFICERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY steps out to be greeted by the waiting JANVRIN..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin. Good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his most winning smile) Tony, please..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANVRIN allows himself a private smile..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY BLAIR and the EQUERRY walk along the corridor, and r the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY shoots his cuffs. Clears his throat. The EQUERRY kno

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY and the EQUERRY enter. Both bow from the neck..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prime Minister, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY walks forward and meets the QUEEN, who, like JANVRIN barely smiles, doesn't make eye contact, shakes his hand, indicates a seat..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY sits, and stares at the QUEEN. Her face is inscrutab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good to see you again. After quite a summer..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN's face. Stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY (cont'd) I'm referring to your visit to India and Pakistan, where your comments about ending historic disagreements went down very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ilence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY (cont'd) And the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. I spoke to the Prime Minister of Malawi, who was saying how much he appreciated your tough stance on Nigeria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant to tell you at the time but you were being monopolised rather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ilence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I imagine those occasions are quite difficult. Twenty-four heads of Government each clamouring for a private audience..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. TONY takes a deep breath, then..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also, we haven't had a chance to speak since THAT week. And I wanted to offer my apologies..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN looks up..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case you'd felt `manhandled' or `managed' in any way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I shall ever understand what happened this summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The circumstances were exceptional, Ma'am. And in the end, you showed great personal strength, courage, and humility.   E

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ou're confusing humility with humiliation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't hear what they were saying in the Mall that Friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still believe History will show it was a good week for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And an even better one for you, Mr Blair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there are fifty-two weeks in a year, Ma'am. And two and a half thousand in a half century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN looks up. Thrown by his compliment..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when people come to assess your legacy, no one will remember those few days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't feel that what respect or affection people might once have had for..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants to say `Me', but instead says..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..this institution has been diminished?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pause..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gather some of your closest advisors were less fulsome in their support..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One or two. But as a leader one has...a different perspective. a beat) I could never have added my voice to the chorus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN looks at TONY, raises an eyebrow..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But let's also not forget the more pragmatic reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That without me there to distract everyone, it'd suddenly become embarrassingly clear how much unchecked power the British Prime Minister actually has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY looks up..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If fifty years of doing MY job has taught me anything, it is that the people doing YOURS generally prefer me with all my faults to some kind of meddling President.. (a beat) Just look at the French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN opens her handbag, and takes out her reading glasses..            E ELIZABETH (cont'd) I suppose we'd better get on with the business in hand..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN looks out of the window. Notices how the sun is setting..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH (cont'd) I do love this time of day. Shall we walk while there's still some sunshine left? I do hope you're a walker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. The clocks go back next week, then it'll be dark by five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY and the QUEEN get to their feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH (cont'd) I always think these meetings stand a better chance of succeeding if the Prime Minister is a walker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOOTMEN open the door as TONY and the QUEEN go out of the Audience Room, and into..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLAIR and the QUEEN turns a corner, and emerge into a corridor from the audience room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, it's how I think best. On my feet. I've never been one for sitting around endlessly. A good walk and fresh air sorts everything out..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unexpectedly, she stops. And suddenly we realize she's be holding something back..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One in four, you said? Wanted to get rid of me? T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For about half an hour. But then you came down to London and all that went away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been hated like that before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. And that must have been difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was. Very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They begin walking again..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever since Diana people want glamour and tears..the grand performance..and I'm not very good at that. I prefer to keep my feelings to myself. Foolishly I believed that's what people wanted from their Queen. Not to make a fuss nor wear one's heart on one's sleeve, duty first... self second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN stops..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's how I was brought up. It's all I've ever known

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One forgets. You were so young when you became Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUEEN drifts off..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was. A girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then pulls herself back..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can see the world has changed. And one must 'modernise'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, perhaps that's where I can help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a twinkle as they set off) Don't get ahead of yourself Prime- minister, I think you'll find that I'm supposed to be advising YOU!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corridor outside. As the QUEEN passes JANVRIN, he surreptitiously looks at his watch, and raises his eyebro The QUEEN smiles..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOOTMEN open double-doors which lead out into the gardens The QUEEN and the PRIME MINISTER walk out..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...what might we expect in your first Parliament?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY clears his throat, then..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Ma'am, top of the list is education reform. We want to radically reduce classroom sizes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our CAMERA slowly pulls back over the gardens, until the QUEEN and TONY are two dots in the distance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time has moved on. Sand has covered the footprints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The momentary hiccup that was `Diana' already long forgotten..
